text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zimbabwe press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Scores of Zimbabwean ex-combatants on Wednesday raided government pensions offices in Harare demanding the release of compensation money suspended by the government four months ago.

- Telecel Zimbabwe, controversial winners of a tender to operate the country's second cellular phone network, had in their possession a copy of the tender document before it was published, tender losers Econet said in an affidavit lodged with the High Court.

- Financial institutions handling funds under the Z$700 million World Bank small enterprise development project will no longer demand that applicants raise 20 percent of the total cost of proposed projects, the World Bank said.
- Some members of the ruling ZANU-PF party have questioned the wisdom of efforts to persuade political maverick Edgar Tekere to rejoin the party.
- The Zimbabwe Development Bank is acquiring Standard Chartered Finance Zimbabwe Limited, a subsidiary of Standard Chartered Bank, which has been on the market for three years.
- The free-falling international gold price, now at its lowest level in almost five years, is threatening the survival of gold mines in Zimbabwe, a local analyst said.

- Zimbabwe's Export Processing Zone Authority and an unnamed local bank are negotiating a Z$200 million project finance scheme with the African Export-Import Bank to strengthen the working capital of projects qualifying to operate in processing zones.

- The government has ratified a Z$385 million loan to finance the rehabilitation of the ailing state-controlled Zimbabwe Iron and Steel Company (Zisco) and has cleared a Chinese firm to undertake the exercise which begins in two weeks.
